>>27985916
That's heartbreaking. I'm sorry, man.

You can't really do much when he's little, except be the best uncle you can, on those occasions where she can't prevent you from meeting (eg: family gatherings). Send birthday cards and Christmas presents, to remind him that you're still there for him and still love him - even if his mum doesn't love you. Ask your parents or other siblings for gift ideas that he will like, since you likely won't be able to think of personalised ones if she keeps you from spending time with him. ALWAYS extend invitations to your sister and her family, whenever you host a family gathering. ALWAYS leave that door open, for your nephew's sake.

Just be careful though. If you regularly try to contact your nephew, she may have grounds to get a restraining order. You won't have done anything wrong at all, but Idk if uncles are given rights to see their nephews, like grandparents are. She may be within her rights to tell you to fuck off, sadly.

When your nephew is little, this is gonna be really hard. But as he grows up and develops more independence, he will have more opportunities to voluntarily spend more time with his uncle. Just make sure the door is always open for him. That's all you can do.

I have family like your sister. I feel you, bro.

Poverty stings. When I was little I only cared about bringing my vision about to the world. >>27986111
You need to take this much more seriously. You want to stop. To keep falling in every other day and keep telling yourself you’ll stop is so far below the minimum acceptable level of seriousness. You need to go to a greater depth. With the understanding that as you do so, you also increase the stakes. You risk hurting yourself and collapsing your soul when you try really hard and you still end up betraying yourself. You can beat yourself into the ground, and end up allowing yourself to quit.

On your longeste streak, you had a degree of seriousness about you, that outpaced anything you’ve experienced since. And you failed because you got away from that. To succeed at this, is to understand that you have to not only stay that serious, but become even more serious.

As you do that, you’re going to start to experience a lot of things bubbling to the surface. You’re going to get annoyed, you’ll feel doubt etc, and since you keep failing, I can conclude that you don’t realize that you’ve started to feel these things until it is too late. They are real concerns that you have to look at and grapple with. Ignore them, and they win. Unfortunately none of that feels good, and that means you have to be willing to feel bad sometimes, while you figure these things out. That’s just the rules of the game. And as you face those things, don’t forget that you said you wanted to quit. And you can do it. Be aware that every decision you make, any thought you let yourself think, you’re creating your identity.

Some of the more toxic thoughts you may feel compelled to underways are: I don’t even care anyway. Just once doesn’t hurt. I’m not doing anything good with my time anyway. I’m not gonna get a girlfriend anyway. I don’t even deserve a good life anyway. I’m useless anyway.

If you pay close attention, you will face yourself like that. All your most toxic shit will come up. And you have to ask yourself if that’s who you want to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because they are never simple truths. They are little mental programs, little units of thought and emotion that you’ve been trained with (and you helped too), and you’ve taken a certain like to them. When people absolutely destroy themselves, there’s a part of them that likes it, at least in the moment. They don’t like it when they have to pick up the tab. That’s why it’s extremely important to always look at what you’re feeling, and what thoughts you’re having, and ask yourself if those thoughts serve you, if they will lead you where you want to go, and if they are who you want to be.

Lots of people choose from two options: letting yourself get away with absolutely anything and telling yourself it’s only human. This makes them soulless and weak. Or they want to be great, but think they can get there by punishing themselves and being an asshole to themselves. Both of these are too emotional. You have to find out that you are greater than your emotions. And truly loving yourself is the same as no longer being a slave to what feels good. It’s to understand that life is not bad because you feel bad right now. You can feel bad, and still be at peace, because you’re doing what you think is right. That will give you self-respect like nothing else. Can’t be bought or faked.

Why SHOULD anyone listen to your opinion? A critic/reviewer can't be just "one guy's opinion." The guy has to speak with some authority that gives his opinion more weight. That can come from academic knowledge, experience as an artist, extensive experience as a consumer, special sensitivity to the art form, or just a masterful way of expressing yourself.

A good reviewer doesn't just say "I liked it" or "I hated it," or even "It was good [or bad]". A good reviewer explains what was good or bad about it and why that was good or bad.

In short, a good reviewer teaches us how to look at the art.

posts.com:
The other day I was on a short vacation with a big group, and a few of my friends convinced me to go to the club with them, and eventually after enough drinks one of them convinced me to dance. I'm extraordinarily well coordinated and athletically capable because of a gymnastics/stunts/martial arts background, so I went up to this mostly empty dance floor, and did some made up pseudo-breakdancing, and it turned out to be convincing enough that the dance floor went from almost empty to completely full by the time I stopped spinning around on the ground, and when I got up, some dude handed me a medal, for a contest I didn't even know the club was having.

At that moment, I swear I felt every girl who was single in that club staring me down. I definitely saw at least 4 different staring directly at me with this like "come get me" look in there eyes.

At that point I sort of just awkwardly danced with some platonic girl friends for a few minutes, and then left back to my hotel room.

So how is it that I can perform something I didn't even know I could do for an entire club full of people without giving it a second thought, and yet I get freaked out enough to instantly sober up just from a few flirty stares? Like how am I supposed to work through that?

It's not just there either. One time I had a girl literally in bed with me (she was a friend we were watching a movie), and she kept coming up with excuses to get more comfortable, get closer to me, after the movie she was like "let's take a nap" and she was like kissing me on the cheek and shit. I could see sex right there on the table, but I couldn't get myself to do anything. I couldn't even think of anything TO do at the time. Every thought felt like the wrong answer.

>tl;dr I freeze like a deer in headlights any time girls show interest in me. wat do?

Life sucks because it's short and always fighting against death. You will never get anything good out of it; money, intelligence and strength won't save you from death. Life hurts; it's painful and sometimes it will put you so low that you can't keep going onward. Hell, you could lose your legs, or your eyes maybe even have your head attached to a computer giving you sustenance but no matter what, you're going out the same way as everybody else and that is where the whole notion of ending it just fucking shatters. You aren't here to be fed happiness, that's just a stupid chemical released in your brain whenever a slight change occurs in your life - utterly pointless and a waste of fucking time hanging your head up missing happiness whenever it passes away into your memories. You're here to fulfil a duty and you don't even realize it. You're fulfilling it every time you speak, every time you listen to someone else speak, hell; it happens when you just stand there doing fucking nothing. You have to be patient until you eat it up to the point it hurts no more. Your psyche is like a shin being conditioned for Muay Thai - the pain is NEVER going to go away but the shin becomes stronger every time it eats pain. That is what you have to remember in the end, that it doesn't matter what you feel like, existence requires you because you yourself exist.

You’re being retarded. You still very much want to cook and write. It seems like the one thing you want most of all. So hold on to that fact.

What does the situation look like then? I think your problem is you have not taken your biggest wish seriously enough. You’ve filled your life with shit that does nothing good for you, and only distracts from your purpose. You’ve allowed insecurities to grow, because it seemed inconvenient to have to be mentally in touch with them at all times. You could decide you are going to beat them, but instead you didn’t show up, and they won by default. And then you have to stop being an addict. These crafts are not here to fill you with easy low effort comfy passion and entertainment. If you want to be passionate, it’s as easy as to stop trying to feel a certain way from your hobbies, but still give everything to them. You get what you earn, and if you don’t feel anything, it’s because you don’t deserve to.

Of course you could also argue that this is how you chose those two crafts in the first place.

But it’s certainly a part of your problem that you think your emotions are your will, and your emotions are where passion resides. Your will is the part of you that still wants to do these things, despite your emotions. And your passion is the part of you that wants to give everything to those crafts, regardless of how it feels to do so. They aren’t emotional qualities, they’re rational. Start listening more to that, and be conscious about your emotions, but don’t use them to evaluate whether or not you should do it. Stop thinking your feelings are a reflection of whether or not you want to. Become as interested in the harsh emotions as the pleasant ones. Be very aware of them. But never let them determine your actions. Learn to do things anyway, and learn to get yourself through things that don’t feel good. Don’t just back away and get depressed ffs

That's kind of true to a limited extent, but the problem is common membership in only a single group isn't really a very good correlation. If you can find several groups which two people are members of you start to show a better correlation, but you will still have differences. There are more differences among individuals in a group than there are broadly among members of one group vs another. You can put people sort of into buckets as far as their goals and such, but the point is you have to pay attention to those things. You can't just say "We need more people, ship in a bunch of immigrants". The demographic and cultural shock can be hugely detrimental because stability is a huge factor in peoples' outlook and future planning, and that has an outsize effect on peoples' spending as well as financial and family planning.

>>27986097
>How feasible is it to live in a place like Thailand for around 500 bucks a month or less?
>rent
Go on fazwaz, or dare I say Craigslist, and see what the prices are. The lowest you could conceivably go on rent is like $150 and that's gonna be outside Farang ghettos and in a non-centralized location. It probably doesn't include utilities either
>muh hostel!
You'd be lucky to find $5 dollars a night
>food
A single Thai dish with rice is like $1.5-3 dollars. Anything western is obviously more expensive. So if you wanted to keep your food budget low you'd have to eat Thai food pretty strictly; either from a hole in the wall restaurant or food cart
>misc
So let's say did that. You're left with $170. That's only about 5000 baht. Lowest monthly rate you could get for a motorbike rental is like 3000 baht = $3 dollars a day. Moto taxis are at least a dollar per trip, even on an app like bolt.
You'd also have to factor in the cost of an ED visa (IMO that's the best visa to stay for ~1 year).

So bottom line you could probably survive "comfortably" imo but that's about it. I don't think you'd find it particularly pleasant though. $1000/mo is a lot more ideal.
You can live off 1000$ a month in Thailand. Vietnam Phillipines

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27984770
i can't really give you any advice specific to your situation, but i can tell you what works for me and you can find a way to apply it to your own life if you want to.
one way to accept that you're not who you want to be is to catch yourself when you start thinking that, and avoid things that make you think that. when you notice your thoughts, consciously and deliberately know that you're feeling like shit (either by saying it out loud, writing it down, or saying it in your internal monologue, something that's very deliberate). then in the same way, remember that you are who you are, and that there's nothing you can do about the past to change you who are now.
the idea is to condition yourself to notice when you feel hollow and to stop the negative self talk by being very intentional. this should stop you from spiraling into a self-pity depressive episode. you won't entirely stop feeling like shit when you see something that makes you feel like shit, but you'll be more in control of how you react to your feelings. it's like doing pushups. at first you might not be able to do 30 pushups, but after a lot of repetition, it takes less effort. when people say stuff like "just do it," what they really mean is that you should consciously set your intentions like this.
another good thing to do is to write down your thoughts so they don't bounce around in your head so much. keep writing until you stop feeling restless. you don't have to look at what you wrote, you can burn it or delete it if you want.
i hope that helps. i tried to be as straightforward as possible, but it's hard to be specific when talking about your internal experiences.

Lol anon! You are overthinking this whole situation…. It’s just one woman…. Let me tell you as a guy in his 30’s who did a 2 year womanizing thing at 30 years old, that it’s kind of funny how things work out with women….

So I decided after becoming single to womanize. But I was really bad at it… I spent months directly approaching women at bars… got some numbers but mainly rejections. And the dates went really bad. I’m talking dates with like 10+ women.

Eventually all of those experiences changed me. It took awhile but you and do something over and over and over again and not experience growth. Like if you played basketball twice a week for 6 months there’s no way you won’t get better.

So eventually I just got better at getting women. But they weren’t coming to me. I was still approaching them but being smoother about it and had better instincts in dates about what to say and how to converse and stuff. I got laid a lot for a while.

Then after like a year of that lifestyle, I woke up one day and was depressed. A hot girl had left my place after a great night and I should have been happy but I wasn’t. I felt shallow. I didn’t want a relationship but I didn’t want to womanize anymore. so suddenly I stopped wanting to get women.

This new perspective came over me and for several weeks I just started doing my own thing. Then all of the sudden hot women started APPROACHING me.

I’d be in the laundry room at my apartment.. I’d be walking down the street in a college area… I’d be sitting by myself at a bar just sipping a whisky minding my business…. It was crazy dude… I just got flocked by women because I had become genuinely aloof. I didn’t even want them anymore.

conclusion: if you want women spend time trying to get them so that you get good at it and burn out and stop wanting them. once you don’t want them anymore, women will start approaching you.

This one girl is no one my man. Relax.

Is there any point to watching any of his videos? Sure, it's always good to hear people out, see what they have to say. It's always good to acquaint ones self with lot's of ideas and perspectives before coming upon an opinion of ones own. One should never blindly parrot the opinions of others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Speaking as someone who read and enjoyed both of his 12 Rules books, he's a quack. He just happened to be in the right place at the right time and said a few things that were pretty basic self-help that some people needed to hear, so a lot of people (myself included) were able to project the most charitable and personally useful interpretations of his words onto him. But the deeper you dive, the more you realise he's an actual lunatic.
His books are... fine... They present pretty no-brainer concepts and just wrap them in a bunch of pseudoscience, psychobabble and spiritualism. If you'd already read them, I would say it is what it is and you don't need to throw the baby out with the bathwater if you got something from them. But if you haven't read them, they're hardly a must read.

I'd say 'The Subtle Art Of Not Giving A Fuck' seems like it presents a lot of the same lessons in a more pragmatic way - granted, that's presumption on my part, since I haven't read that one and have only seen a few videos by/interviews with the author. But they seem similar in the sense of taking responsibility for your life and being more mindful/proactive towards your emotional responses to things - basically giving yourself an attitude adjustment. But, fitting title, The Subtle Art is lightyears less pretentious, which might be doubly better for you if you struggle with feeling like you're not smart enough. You don't need to deal with JBP pontificating for pages on end about his made up nonsense peppered with biblical allusions and convenient misinformation just to explain something as simple as 'stop and smell the roses'. While reading the 12 Rules books, I'd routinely forget the rule that any given chapter was even trying to explain while reading it, simply because he goes on such weird and elaborate tangents.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27982527
No experience on Amphetamine (Elvanse is Lisdexamfetmine, which is basically metabolised into Amphetamine). I do have experience with Methylphenidate tho which is the other stimulant drug commonly used to treat ADHD.

I originally had a long winding faggy multi-paragraph response written out, but that was cockblocked for being too long so if you have any specific questions I'll be happy to answer. The topics I originally covered was how the medication felt at first; how it helps and what I still struggle with; and effects on appetite. Keep in mind that how you react to methylphenidate and amphetamine can vary from person to person. A lot of people respond better to Amphetamine, but most people will benefit from either Methylphenidate or Amphetamine.

To summarise what I wrote down a little, although stimulants give me the tools to be more productive I still have to put in willpower. They don't give me any sort of energy or motivational boost, and I still struggle with old habits. They don't turn me into a zombie tho.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>27982527
I was about that age, maybe a year or two older. In my experience with dexedrine XR (same drug, just different delivery method) it started out like a magic bullet that seemed to fix all my issues that I had been struggling with and I was able to accomplish more in a year or two than I had in all the years previous. I wondered if that was how normies felt. Want something? Just work at it and achieve it.
No such thing as a free lunch though. Over time it began to work differently or not at all, and it has its own sides and changes that it will make to your mood and personality that may be unfavorable.
I went off it for a couple years and then within the past few months back on. Why? Life is bullshit one way or another I guess. It helps enough to get through the day to day struggle but the "magic" never returned even after two years so I guess the changes are permanent once your body/brain learns it.
From there you can look for ways to boost it or increase the dosage but it's not really worth it (also increases the sides) so I've never done it. It would be better to use it only "as needed" like for school or work, maybe take weekends off and extended breaks whenever you can. I did at first but eventually it's a bit like a cup of coffee where you look for that boost every day even to just do mundane shit.

https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/premenstrual-syndrome/symptoms-causes/syc-20376780

All humans are irrational because we live our lives internally and externally based off of perception. We also do not have perfect factual memory. Many of our memories are steeped with emotions and its our emotional reaction to a situation that we tend to remember more than the event itself. It is why eyewitness accounts are less credible than other forms of proof at trials. Especially eye witness accounts from at a distance.

If you want to understand anyone better who tends to have a reaction to something that you do not understand the reasons for ask them about the thoughts that lead them to these emotions. Be a thoughtful and attentive listener if they choose to open up about something. Not everyone is self aware of their internal machinations and it may have not occurred to them to think about why they react in the way that they do.

For example I am curious why you do not think of yourself as a misogynist when you use misogynistic terms like hysteria? Perhaps you did not know that the term is no longer used and is not considered a real medical condition in the DSM-5. Perhaps when you compare yourself to others in your life you do not seem so bad in your opinion. I hope I am not coming off as judgemental and that my message is of some use to you.
